conclusion: The wire frame consists of a semi-circular arc and a straight line segment, and the plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The straight part of the wire frame experiences a force F.
The force on a straight conductor of length L carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = I L B.
For the straight part of the wire frame, let L = 2r (the diameter of the semi-circle), so F = I (2r) B.
For the semi-circular arc, the length of the wire is πr.

The force on a curved conductor in a uniform magnetic field can be found by integrating the force over the length of the conductor. However, due to symmetry and the perpendicular orientation, the effective force can be considered as if it were acting along the diameter.
The force on the semi-circular arc is F_arc = I (πr) B.
The total force is the vector sum of the forces on the straight and curved parts. Since both forces are in the same direction, they add up directly: F_total = F + F_arc.
Substituting the expressions for F and F_arc: F_total = I (2r) B + I (πr) B = I r B (2 + π).
We know F = I (2r) B, so I r B = F/2.
Substitute I r B into the total force equation: F_total = (F/2) (2 + π) = F (1 + π/2).
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is F_total = F (1 + π/2).
